abstracts.cdata!:
The Education and Health Project for
            Kosovo had the following ratings:  the outcome was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both satisfactory. There are
            both project specific and general lessons to be learned to
            ensure that such approaches are improved in the future in
            the following areas: (1) Multi-sectoral projects: The
            project assumed that the institutional capacity was similar
            for the health and education sectors. This was not the case
            in this project. From the start support for education policy
            changes received strong support from the UNMIK education
            office, and the capacity built there sustained project
            activities. Less trained manpower available in the health
            sector and changes in Ministry staff affected the ability of
            the government to carry out the policy changes anticipated.
            (2) Choice of Project Activities: The project activities
            were overcomplicated and over sophisticated for the
            timeframe. There was no need to include social protection as
            a component. In addition, a pragmatic blend of policy and
            praxis might have ensured more ownership. Preparation for
            the school grant scheme undertaken at the end of the project
            reinforced the message of decentralization which the project
            was sending on education. Similarly the introduction of
            training for public health care physicians and nurses
            towards the end of the project contributed not only to the
            impact of the project on policy formation but also health
            care delivery.  Research in the Western world on introducing
            innovation into government recognizes that this can come as
            a response to crisis. This project took such an opportunity.
            However key factors in the successful introduction of
            innovations include:  (a) Keeping them simple in approach;
            (b) Making them easy to execute; (c) Shooting for quick
            results; (d) Making them appealing to the widest
            constituency possible and (e) Keeping them apolitical.
            Application of the above principles to project design might
            have increased impact and enhanced its ultimate
            sustainability.  A central Project Implementation Unit for
            both components would have facilitated coordination and
            oversight, particularly when there were changes in government.

repnme.cdata!:
Kosovo, Federal Republic of Yugoslavia -
            Education and Health Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Education and Health Project for
            Kosovo aims to improve efficiency and equity in public
            resource allocation for education; create a knowledge base
            for education; and improve the efficiency of public
            financing for health services. There are three main project
            components. This component focuses on education: 1) It
            assists the policy design, implementation planning, and
            training of a comprehensive decentralized system of
            education funding; and develops management systems and
            related software aimed at capturing essential school data
            and information, and builds an information culture. 2) It
            strengthens governance and the institutional capacity of the
            University of Pristina by providing technical support to
            legislate the university's mandate and operating
            procedures, and develops its strategic planning and
            management capacity. 3) It develops the staff's
            capacity to define modern standards and assess student
            performance. 4) It develops the education department's
            governance and management structures. The second component
            develops a health and welfare strategy through 1) designing
            and implementing mechanisms for the financing system; and
            providing technical assistance to develop a social
            protection strategy; 2) strengthening the capacity of the
            health insurance fund; and 3) preparing an implementation
            plan for restructuring the health sector. The third
            component provides critical information on the project
            concerning financing and the public's use of social services.
